newsitem.title: DUBAI: Dubal criticises EAA over aluminium import tariff.
newsitem.headline: Dubal criticises EAA over aluminium import tariff.

text.p: Dubai Aluminium Co Ltd (Dubal) on Monday slammed the European Aluminium Association (EAA) for keeping a six percent tariff on aluminium imports.
"Mr Legrand's position demonstrated the discriminatory focus of this tariff by leaders of some of the European aluminium companies," Dubal said in a statement sent to Reuters.
It was referring to last week's comments by EAA chairman Bernard Legrand saying the European Union tariff on imports of primary aluminium would be maintained "for the time being".

He said the duty allowed European aluminium producers to compete against cheap imports from Russia and Middle East Gulf producers. It also compensated European producers for fluctuations in the dollar, he said.
But Dubal said there was little similarity between most Russian smelters and the two Gulf producers -- Dubal and Aluminium Bahrain (Alba).

"The Gulf smelters are producers of high quality product operating to the highest environmental standards and it would not take long to develop beneficial business partnerships with major European fabricators if the tariff barrier were removed."
It said many Russian smelters produced "low quality offgrade material supplied at discount rates into Europe".
"Often, where duty is paid, it can be offset by those major European companies who export products into other world markets and obtain duty claw back," a practice Dubal likened to dumping.

Dubal chief executive Ian Rugeroni said the tariff created various anomalies, including the fact non-EU Norway was the major beneficiary and Russian metal could be processed through Norwegian and Eastern bloc smelters and supplied duty free to Europe.

"Why should Europe expect to promote the growth of smelters around the world in order to sell its technology and equipment and then deny those countries access to 30 percent of the world's aluminium market?" he said.
Government-owned Dubal is in the process of expanding annual capacity by over 50 percent to 375,000 tonnes.
The Gulf's other smelter, Alba has capacity of 460,000 tonnes and plans to add another 36,500 tonnes in 1997. Oman is also studying plans to set up a 480,000 tonnes a year smelter.
Power to generate the smelting process is one of the single biggest costs of production. The region's natural gas provides the industry with the power supply it requires.
